utterances: Post-traumatic stress disorder, substance abuse, family problems, it's harder for them to pay attention to some of the things that they did before the hurricane.
For now, most of the department's 1,500 officers are living on a cruise ship docked on the Mississippi River, and the department's command center is the lobby of a downtown hotel.
Laura Sullivan, NPR News.
This is Day to Day from NPR News.
I'm Alex Cohen.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
President Obama unveiled his 10-year budget plan today.
It includes higher taxes for families earning more than $250,000, and for families earning less than $150,000, they'd get a tax break.
The government hopes people would then feel emboldened to go out and spend some of their extra cash.
Well, if you're like me, you're not feeling the urge to go on a wild shopping spree much these days.
But reporter Nishat Kurwa in San Francisco has found a way to hit the stores without taking a big financial hit.
It does involve a little negotiating.
What's your credit card debt like these days?
I'd rather not say.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
The guy needs to be doing some serious belt-tightening.

Coming from working in retail as my first job, you know, we all hated people that tried to just come in there and get deals because they thought they were entitled to deals when the reality is, like, you know, you can either pay or you can go somewhere else.
It's...
Brian Nickerson, director of shopping at Internet Brands, says in a bad economy, it seems everything is negotiable.
It never hurts to ask, and you can be amazed definitely at the deals you can find.
I think retailers are concerned about both their top-line revenue and the margins that they can achieve on that revenue.
You walk in; the person seems like they're in a bad mood; you have to be a little empathetic.
If they're in, like, a funny mood, you maybe joke around with them a little bit; you kind of build a rapport.
And then when you've gotten to be their NBF, their new best friend, then you go for the jugular.
Yeah, I don't know, it still seems a little bit like you're kind of playing them when they're trying to do their job.
So, I guess if morally you're OK with it, then you can do it.
Oh, boy.
This one's going to be a challenge.
So, key for Hussein here?
Adopt the whole there's-no-such-thing-as-a-stupid-question approach.
Engage the target.
Ask for no sales tax or whatever?
Yeah, that would be a good start.
You should be like, you know what?
This is, like...
Yeah.
My name is Sherry Lynn Galorro(ph), and I live in New Buffalo, Michigan.
I'm a McCain supporter, and I put my sign up in the yard, and one day it was there, the next day it was gone.
Both of them magically disappeared.
I was very angry.
(Soundbite of song ""Stars and Stripes Forever"")
My name is Rick Tuttle.
I own a little bookstore in Three Oaks, Michigan.
What I did was instead of replacing the sign, I put a sign out that says, hey, you, put back my Obama sign.
Oh, we had a volunteer come in today who said that her sign was stolen.
And so, they put up a sign that said, for every Obama sign you steal from this yard, I'm donating $50 more to the Obama campaign.'
I have one friend who - she's replaced her sign twice now, and she's put grease on the borders of it, so when you pick it up, it hopefully will stick to your hand.
Well, my name is Leo Jovanovic.
I live on Old Valley Road outside of Three Oaks.
And I decided to put electric fence around it.
There's a four strands of electric wire, roughly six by six square, and the wires are about 12 inches apart, and there's four wires up.
It ain't going to I kill you, you know, but if somebody wants to touch that wire they're going to be - they're going to get a little surprise.
(Soundbite of song ""Stars and Stripes Forever"")
I'm Mary Jo Nallenweg and I'm the village clerk and treasurer for the Village of Michiana.
I had a resident come in and said that he'd (unintelligible).
I think they should be prosecuted.
It's not very nice.
It's not very Christian.
That's (unintelligible) when you go through the system.
(Soundbite of song ""Stars and Stripes Forever"")
I'm kind of disturbed by the undercurrent that seems to be running through this political campaign.
I know there have always been signs stolen here and there throughout ever campaign, but I haven't heard of instances like this before.
So, this is something new to me at least.
It could be, you know, another sign of how divided we are and how much healing needs to take place after the election's over.
I'm about to put back the signs.
I told my wife that this is the third attempt of, you know, trying to keep the sign on our property, and if this one gets stolen, then I'll probably end up sleeping in a combine with a shotgun.
So, yeah, I'm pretty passionate about keeping my Obama sign.
I've been so angry about them stealing it.
I don't know what I'm going to do the third time.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Don't want to cry and I don't want to get any angrier.
I just want them to stop doing this.
Our story on the disappearance of Obama and McCain yard signs was produced by Dan Collison and Elizabeth Meister for Long Haul Productions.
(Soundbite of music)
There's more Day to Day after this.
Now we've got more on the food crisis from a different angle.
Activism in the United States.
Many Americans are tracking the unrest over food prices and possible famines.
The crisis includes not only the deadly riots in Somalia, but protests in African nations including Egypt, Cameroon and Burkina Faso.
The high price tags on basic foodstuffs could lead to malnutrition and even starvation.
Activist and actor Danny Glover is trying to get the food crisis on the government's agenda.
He's the chairman of the board for TransAfrica Forum, and he recently spoke to members of Congress about the impact of the food crisis on children around the world.
Danny, welcome back to the show.
Thank you.
So what was the purpose of your trip to Capitol Hill?
Well, I was part of a panel and a briefing for Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee's committee on the current food crisis.
As you know, there is going to be - and you may not know- there's going to be a Congressional delegation that's going down to Haiti.
But as we all know, the crisis itself is not simply stationed in Haiti.
It's a problem with the global South and poor countries in Africa and over there in South Asia, within Latin America.
Many people know you as an actor and producer, but not everyone knows that you're chair of the board for TransAfrica Forum.
How did you get involved in looking at the issues that affect the global South, as you call it, and specifically this food issue?
Well, I have a long-standing relationship with TransAfrica Forum, which dates back to the anti-apartheid movement.
I supported the abolition of apartheid, doing the work of the great South African playwright, Athol Fugard.
But also by my involvement in the African Liberty Support Committee and other organizations.
So there's a long relationship with them.
The question of food is very much tied in to the question of development and certainly the question of infrastructure, building and also the question of health as well.
I mention Africa because countries in the global South, or as we refer to them, the undeveloped world, have had a very peculiar relationship with the countries from the North, the developed world.
And a great deal of that is functioned around trade.

Certainly, we who look at countries that at one point had been sustainable in food production, often being able to export food, now are dependent upon buying food at exorbitant prices, even before the current crisis, which does not allow them to put money in social development, in education, in healthcare.
Yeah.
Now, you said that your - one of your GPS stations moved almost 13 feet.
Is that common, something like that?
Thank you.
